p: Therefore, overcoming conventional sustainability perspectives implies the recognition of other worldviews and environmental rationalities (Leff 2006), diverse in the ways of being-knowing-living. While instrumental narratives based on a fragmented and disenchanted worldview lead to the present scenario of uncertainties, plural narratives can contribute to re-enchantment, “suspending the sky” and “postponing the end of the world” (Krenak 2019). Consequently, shedding light on the pluriverse might inspire hope and expand horizons for regenerative possibilities toward desirable futures. Nature-based solutions to face climate change and biodiversity loss, thus, require narratives that transcend the disjunctive and reductionist thinking and binary splits between nature and culture, like Buen Vivir. From a systemic perspective, climate actions should result from a deep process of sociocultural transformations, presupposing the overcoming of the coloniality intrinsic to the materialist and accumulative logic (Quijano 2000).
